Trial_Design.evidence: This single-centre, open-label, randomised controlled trial included 128 patients

Participants.evidence: 128 patients undergoing elective surgeries that required central vein cannulation

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomised to either the anterior out-of-plane or in-plane technique

Objective.evidence: The primary objective of the study was to compare the first-pass success rate

Method_Outcome.evidence: First-pass success rates, puncture and cannulation times, needle redirections, additional punctures, and complications were recorded

Number_Randomised.evidence: This single-centre, open-label, randomised controlled trial included 128 patients

Number_Analysed.evidence: Successful cannulation was achieved in 119 patients

Result_Outcome.evidence: The first-pass success rate was significantly higher with the anterior out-of-plane approach (95%) compared to the in-plane approach (77%) ( P < 0.05)

Harms.evidence: fewer needle redirections, punctures, and complications, including arterial punctures (1 vs 5), were observed
